front.title: NetJSON: data interchange format for networks

abstract.t: NetJSON is a data interchange format based on JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) designed to describe the basic building blocks of layer2 and layer3 networking.
It defines several types of JSON objects and the manner in which they are combined to represent a network: configuration of devices, monitoring data, network topology and routing information.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: NetJSON is a format for describing data about layer 2 and layer 3 networks using JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) [RFC7159].
The format is concerned with the basic building blocks that compose a computer network (devices, monitoring data, routing, topology).
The concepts in NetJSON are not new; they are derived from existing conventions consolidated in open source projects related to the networking field, such as:

list.t: the Community Networking Markup Language [CNML]
open source implementations of network monitoring tools like [Nagios]
dynamic routing protocols like [OLSRd] ([RFC3626] and [RFC7181]), [Babel] ([RFC6126]), [Batman-adv] and [BMX]
linux distributions like [OpenWRT]

section.t: These concepts have been streamlined to encourage interoperability between network centric web applications using JSON.

section.title: Motivatons
section.t: Developing software that deals with networks is harder than it should be.

Developers have to take into account all the differences between vendors, operating systems, routing protocols, hardware and (when working with community networks) with the different approaches of each community.
Very often, each vendor develops an entire stack that works exclusively with its own hardware and software.
There exist many libraries and web apps for networking, but it is very hard to make them interoperable, that is, making them talk and understand one another with minimum effort.
This is an attempt to invert this trend, following the successful example of the GeoJSON format.
By defining common data structures we can allow developers to focus on their goals instead of having to struggle with the differences of each vendor, firmware, routing protocol or community.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The ordering of the members of any JSON object defined in this document MUST be considered irrelevant, as specified by RFC RFC7159.

Some examples use the combination of a JavaScript single line comment (//) followed by an ellipsis (...) as placeholder notation for content deemed irrelevant by the authors. These placeholders must of course be deleted or otherwise replaced, before attempting to validate the corresponding JSON code example.
Whitespace is used in the examples inside this document to help illustrate the data structures, but is not required. Unquoted whitespace is not significant in JSON.

list.t: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON), and the terms "object", "member", "name", "value", "array", "number", "true", "false", and "null" are to be interpreted as defined in RFC RFC7159.

The term "NetJSON type(s)" (sometimes abbreviated to "type(s)") refers to (one of) the five case-sensitive strings: "DeviceConfiguration", "DeviceMonitoring", "NetworkRoutes", "NetworkGraph" and "NetworkCollection".
The term "JSON Schema" (sometimes abbreviated as "schema"), refers to JSON-Schema version 4.

section.title: NetJSON Object
section.t: NetJSON always consists of a single object, referred to as the "NetJSON object" below.

list.t: The top level of NetJSON text MUST be a JSON object.
The NetJSON object MUST have a member with the name "type". The value of the member MUST be one of the NetJSON types defined below.
The NetJSON object MAY have any number of other members not explicitly defined in this specification, referred as "custom members" below. Implementations MUST ignore unrecognized custom members.
Before adding any custom member, implementers SHOULD read the NetJSON extension registry in order to find existing custom members to reuse or to learn how to officially submit new custom members.

section.title: NetJSON types
section.t: NetJSON defines the following types:

list.t: NetworkRoutes;
NetworkGraph;
DeviceConfiguration;
DeviceMonitoring;
NetworkCollection.

section.title: NetworkRoutes
section.t: Definition: a list of routes of a dynamic routing protocol or statically configured on the device.
Goals: show internal information of a routing protocol for monitoring and debugging purposes.
Example: A.1. NetworkRoutes Example.
JSON Schema: B.1. NetworkRoutes Schema.
A NetworkRoutes object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: name of the routing protocol implementation, may be "static" when representing static routes
version of the routing protocol implementation, may be null when representing static routes
name of main routing metric used by the routing protocol to determine the best routes when sending packets, may be null when representing static routes

section.t: A NetworkRoutes object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: string indicating the revision from which the routing protocol deamon binary was built (eg: git hash, svn revision)
arbitrary identifier of the router on which the protocol is running (eg: ip, mac, hash)

section.title: Route Objects
section.t: Each route object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: the ip address, prefix or mac address that will be matched to the destination of the traffic
the ip address or mac address of the next hop
the interface the traffic will be going to, it may be omitted when representing static routes

value of the routing metric indicating the outgoing cost to reach the destination; lower cost is better, it MAY be omitted when representing static routes Infinity and NaN are not allowed in accordance with the JSON RFC

section.t: Each route object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: human readable representation of the cost member
the source address of the route (used in source-specific routing)

section.title: NetworkGraph
section.t: Definition: a list of nodes and links known by a node.
Goals: visualization of network topology, collect network topology from distance vector protocols, monitoring.
Example: A.2. NetworkGraph Example.
JSON Schema: B.2. NetworkGraph Schema.
A NetworkGraph object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: name of the routing protocol implementation, may be "static" when representing static routes
version of the routing protocol implementation, may be null when representing static routes
name of main routing metric used by the routing protocol to determine the best routes when sending packets, may be null when representing static routes

section.t: A NetworkGraph object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: string indicating the revision from which the routing protocol deamon binary was built (eg: git hash, svn revision)
arbitrary identifier of the router on which the protocol is running (eg: ip, mac, hash)
a human readable label for the topology

section.title: Node Objects
section.t: Each node object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: arbitrary identifier of the node, eg: ipv4, ipv6, mac address, hash, ecc.

section.t: Each node object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: human readable label of the node
array of strings representing additional addresses (mac/ip) which can be used to communicate with the node
object which MAY contain any arbitrary member; these arbitrary members SHOULD be visualized by user interface software

section.title: Link Objects
section.t: Each link object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: value of the routing metric indicating the outgoing cost to reach the destination; lower cost is better, it MAY be omitted when representing static routes; Infinity and NaN are not allowed in accordance with the JSON RFC

section.t: Each link object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: human readable representation of the cost member;
object which MAY contain any arbitrary member; these arbitrary members SHOULD be visualized by user interface software

section.title: DeviceConfiguration
section.t: Definition: configuration and properties of a network device.
Goals: configuration storage and management, import and export configurations between different monitoring tools or network controllers.
Example: A.3. DeviceConfiguration Example.
JSON Schema: B.3. DeviceConfiguration Schema.
A DeviceConfiguration object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:
A DeviceConfiguration object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: object that contains general information related to the network device, see General Object for details
hardware information related to the network device, see Hardware Object for details
operating system information, see Operating System Object for details
array of objects that represent how network interfaces are configured on the device, see Interface Objects for details
array of objects that represent the configuration of radios available on the system, see Radio Objects for details
array of objects that represent static routes configured on the device, see Static Route Objects for details
an array of strings denoting DNS servers configured on the device
an array of strings denoting DNS search paths configured on the device

section.title: General Object
section.t: The "general" object of DeviceConfiguration MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: system timezone; the value of this member MUST be one of the values present in the Time Zone Database maintained by IANA
email address of the maintainer of the network device
free-form textual description of the network device
IPv6 Unique Local Address prefix applicable to every network interface

section.title: Hardware Object
section.t: The "hardware" object of DeviceConfiguration MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: version of the device (as in the OpenWRT Table of Hardware)

section.title: Operating System Object
section.t: The "operating_system" object of DeviceConfiguration MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: name of the operating system or firmware
version name or version number of the operating system
revision from which the firmware binary was built (eg: git hash, svn revision)

section.title: Interface Objects
section.t: Each object contained in the "interfaces" array of DeviceConfiguration MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: name of the interface, MUST NOT be longer than 15 characters, MUST accept all characters except whitespace
RECOMMENDED possible values for this field are: "ethernet", "wireless", "bridge", "virtual", "loopback" or "other". Additional values MAY be allowed if needed.

section.t: Each object contained in the "interfaces" array of DeviceConfiguration MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: value of the Maximum Transmission Unit setting, defaults to 1500
value of the TX queue length setting
indicates whether the interface should be automatically started after reboot, defaults to true
indicates whether the interface is disabled, defaults to false
valid only if "type" is "bridge"; array of interface names (strings) representing the bridged interfaces
wireless settings, valid only if "type" is "wireless"; see Wireless Object.

section.title: Address Objects
section.t: Each object contained in the "addresses" member of an Interface Object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:
Each object contained in the "addresses" member of an Interface Object MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: ipv4 or ipv6 address, MUST be present if type is "static"

section.title: Wireless Object
section.t: The object contained in the "wireless" member of an Interface Object which has type "wireless" MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: MUST refer to the name of one of the radios defined in Radio Objects
wireless mode, allowed values are: access_point, station, adhoc, wds, monitor, 802.11s
ESSID of the network, MUST NOT be longer than 32 characters

section.t: The object contained in the "wireless" member of an Interface Object which has type "wireless" MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: BSSID, usually used in "adhoc" or "wds" mode
whether the SSID is hidden from the user, if omitted MUST default to false
distance between the access point and the furthest client in meters, MUST NOT be less than 1
specifies the frame size at which the transmitter must use the RTS/CTS protocol, MUST be between 0 and 2346
indicates the maximum frame size, MUST be between 0 and 2346
encryption settings, if omitted MUST default to disabled encryption, see Encryption Object

section.title: Encryption Object
section.t: The object contained in the "encryption" member of a Wireless Object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: encryption protocol; the RECOMMENDED allowed values are: wep_open, wep_shared, wpa_personal, wpa2_personal, wpa_personal_mixed, wpa_enterprise, wpa2_enterprise, wpa_enterprise_mixed, wps

section.t: The object contained in the "encryption" member of a Wireless Object MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: string representing security ciphers; the RECOMMENDED allowed values are: auto, ccmp, tkip and tkip+ccmp
whether to disable encryption, SHOULD default to false

section.title: Radio Objects
section.t: Each object contained in the "radios" array of DeviceConfiguration MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: arbitrary name of the radio device
wireless protocol used, the RECOMMENDED allowed values are: 802.11ac, 802.11n, 802.11b, 802.11g, 802.11a

section.t: Each object contained in the "radios" array of DeviceConfiguration MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: name of the physical device to which the radio object is related to, optional because usually autodetected
two digit country code in ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 format, case insensitive
whether the radio should be disabled or not, defaults to false

section.title: Static Route Objects
section.t: Each object contained in the "routes" array of DeviceConfiguration MUST define the following REQUIRED members:

texttable.c: destination address of the static route
next hop address for the static route

section.title: DeviceMonitoring
section.t: Definition: information that indicates the behaviour of a device that changes over time.
Goals: ouput, collect, parse and visualize monitoring data of a network device.
Example: A.4. DeviceMonitoring Example.
JSON Schema: B.4. DeviceMonitoring Schema.
A DeviceMonitoring object MUST define the following REQUIRED members:
A DeviceMonitoring object MAY also define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: object that contains monitoring data that is related to the whole device, see General Object for details
describes how hardware resources are being used by the system, see Resources Object for details
array of objects that represent monitoring data related to specific network interfaces, see Interface Objects for details

section.title: General Object
section.t: The "general" object of DeviceMonitoring MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

section.title: Resources Object
section.t: The "resources" object of DeviceMonitoring MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: array with 3 numeric values representing load average values respectively in the last minute, in the last 5 minutes and in the last 15 minutes
object describing RAM usage, SHOULD contain the following RECOMMENDED members: "total", "free", "buffered", "cache" (unit: bytes)
object describing swap memory usage, SHOULD contain the following RECOMMENDED members: "total", "free" (unit: bytes)
object describing connection state, SHOULD contain two RECOMMENDED objects: "ipv4", "ipv6", each object MUST have two members: "tcp" and "udp", indicating the number of open connections
object describing running processes, SHOULD contain the RECOMMENDED member "running" and MAY contain the following RECOMMENDED members: "sleeping", "blocked", "zombie", "stopped", "paging".
object describing CPU usage, MAY contain the following OPTIONAL members: "frequency" (MHz), "user", "system, "nice", "idle", "iowait", "irq", "softirq"
object describing flash usage, SHOULD contain the following RECOMMENDED members: "total", "free" (unit: bytes)
object describing storage usage, SHOULD contain the following RECOMMENDED members: "total", "free" (unit: bytes)

section.title: Interface Objects
section.t: Each object contained in the "interfaces" array of DeviceMonitoring MAY define the following OPTIONAL members:

texttable.c: object providing detailed monitoring data related to the interface, it MAY contain the following OPTIONAL members: "collisions", "rx_frame_errors", "tx_compressed", "multicast", rx_length_errors", "tx_dropped", "rx_bytes", "rx_missed_errors", "tx_errors", "rx_compressed", "rx_over_errors", "tx_fifo_errors", "rx_crc_errors", "rx_packets", "tx_heartbeat_errors", "rx_dropped", "tx_aborted_errors", "tx_packets", "rx_errors", "tx_bytes", "tx_window_errors", "rx_fifo_errors", "tx_carrier_errors"

section.title: NetworkCollection
section.t: Definition: collection of NetJSON objects.
Goals: allow to list various netjson objects into a coherent group, eg:

list.t: list graphs of different routing protocols running on the same device;
list all the routes of a multi-topology capable routing protocol;
list devices of a network.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: NetJSON types and their schemas are JSON values. As such, all security considerations defined in RFC 7159 apply.

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: NetJSON does not impose to publish, send or collect sensitive information.
NetJSON only describes how to represent data, each implementer MAY decide:

list.t: which optional members to publish (sensitive data can be omitted)
how to publish it (public, basic auth, token auth, ecc.)
how to collect it
which parts should be collected
